People’s Republic of China: Capacity Building for

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2009 country programming mission for the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
the government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide capacity development 
technical assistance (TA) for capacity building for information and communication technology 
(ICT)-based  industrial  waste  management.  The  TA  will  help  the  government  enhance  its 
institutional capacity for industrial waste management, and improve its management information 
system and monitoring mechanisms using information technology. The TA is consistent with the 
focus of ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2008–2010 for the PRC;1 and ADB’s Strategy 
2020,2 which supports environmental protection and capacity development to reinforce inclusive 
growth. ADB fielded a TA fact-finding mission during 24–27 July 2010 to prepare the TA report.3 
The mission and the government reached an agreement4 on the project impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for 
consulting services. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Aside from water and air pollution control, industrial waste management, particularly 
hazardous waste management, has become an emerging challenge in the PRC. Without proper 
management of industrial waste, it could undermine the PRC’s achievements of decades of 
economic growth, and affect people’s health and welfare, and environmental quality. 
 
3.  The  government  conducted  its  first  national  inventory  of  pollutants  in  2008,  which 
included basic environmental data of industries, and a database of key pollution sources for all 
sectors. The inventory covered industrial, agricultural, and urban pollution sources. In 2009, the 
volume of industrial waste was about 2.04 billion tons—an increase of 7.3% from that of 2008, 
of  which  about  1.38  billion  tons  of  the  waste  was  recycled  and  reused.  The  amount  of 
hazardous waste in 2009 was about 14.3 million tons, of which 8.31 million tons was reused.5 
The balance of the waste was either stored or disposed of. There is an increasing trend of trans-
boundary transfer and disposal of industrial waste, particularly of hazardous waste, between 
counties and regions in the country. There has been no investigation or survey to assess the 
quality of the storage sites and disposal facilities because of the lack of a monitoring and 
reporting system, which casts doubt on the appropriateness of the waste storage and disposal 
facilities, and possibly, secondary contamination of the environment. 
 
4.  The Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP) is responsible for establishing policies 
and regulations on industrial waste management, and monitoring enforcement of the regulations 
by provincial and municipal governments. The government prepared a national project in 2008 
to construct solid waste management centers at the MEP and in 31 provinces, and a national 
information system  on solid  waste  management.  The  national  information  system  is  being 
developed  following  a  feasibility  study  conducted  in  2004  that  comprises  six  subsystems: 
(i) source management, (ii) permit approval and management, (iii) waste transfer management,

(iv) waste export management, (v) waste import management, and (vi) emergency response 
support. Once the system is developed, an enterprise will have access to the system in each 
county and input data online. A local environmental protection bureau (EPB) will be responsible 
for verifying the enterprise’s information before endorsing the data to the information center at a 
provincial  EPB.  The  provincial  EPB  will  be  able  to  verify  the  county-level  information  by 
compiling the data and calculating the waste volume of each category of waste in the province. 
The MEP information center will be able to use the system to conduct inquiries, compile data, 
and analyze statistics for industrial waste management.    
 
5.  The  MEP  faced  several  major  challenges  during  the  establishment  of  the  national 
information system, including (i) the availability of qualified staff to supervise and administer 
industrial waste management; (ii) an ineffective manifest system for monitoring the generation, 
transportation, and final disposal of industrial waste as a result of the lengthy paperwork and 
difficulty in keeping track of records;6 (iii) weak institutional capacity for contingency planning 
and  emergency  responses  to  control  and  contain  accidents  caused  by  mishandling  of 
hazardous waste; and (iv) an outdated information system that does not meet the current and 
medium-term  needs  for  industrial  waste  management.  For  example,  the  management  of 
electronics waste, which has been regulated since 2009, is not in the system. The framework of 
the information system needs to be updated to include industrial waste that is being regulated. 
MEP staff also needs to be trained in the system development and to have their system 
management skills enhanced. 
 
6.  The  government  requested  ADB  to  provide  TA  to  help  the  MEP  to  (i) review  the 
framework of its national information system, and make recommendations for its improvement 
and expansion to meet the needs for industrial waste management for the following 5–10 years; 
(ii) improve the institutional capacity for industrial waste management, including management of 
the  information  system,  data  collection  and  analysis,  information  sharing  and  uses,  and 
reporting; and (iii) prepare guidelines on the establishment and management of the industrial 
waste management information system.  
 
7.  ADB provided TA in 2005 to help develop MEP (then the State Environmental Protection 
Agency) regional supervision centers; and in 2009, additional TA on Strengthening Enforcement 
of  Environmental  Laws  and  Regulations  to  improve  the  enforcement  capacity  of  national, 
regional, and local environmental agencies.7 ADB has also been assisting the government’s 
municipal waste management investment.8 In October 2009, ADB provided regional TA to 
improve public services through ICT in three ADB developing member countries.9 The review of 
ICT project experiences in several countries shows the urgency of enhancing governments’ 
capacity of using ICT in a coordinated and organized manner. A range of activities will need to 
be considered, including a sector-specific ICT road map, and ICT project management in each 
sector. The TA will build on the achievements of the ADB projects, and draw lessons from these

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The expected impact of the TA will be improved industrial waste management in major 
industrial provinces. It is expected that the TA will support the MEP in meeting its targets and 
goals of using information technology to establish databases and management frameworks for 
environmental protection as portrayed in the government’s Eleventh Five-Year Plan, 2006–
2010; and of improving hazardous waste management in the upcoming Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 
2011–2015. The outcome of the TA will be strengthened capacity for the development and 
maintenance of the industrial waste management information system. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will (i) review the current national framework of the industrial waste management 
information  system,  (ii)  assess  its  comprehensiveness  in  meeting  the  needs  of  existing 
regulatory requirements, (iii) improve the institutional capacity for managing the system, and 
(iv) make recommendations for strengthening the institutional capacity and improvement of the 
information system. The TA will also conduct consultation meetings with the executing agency, 
and  municipal  and  provincial  EPBs;  and  carry  out  a  needs  assessment  to  prepare  an 
institutional capacity development plan and conduct related training. The TA will support the 
establishment of the national industrial waste management information system at the MEP, and 
municipal and provincial governments; and develop institutional capacity for managing and 
maintaining the information system. Key activities for achieving TA outputs are described below. 
 
10.  Output  1:  Framework  of  the  industrial waste  management  information  system 
updated. The TA consultants will (i) review the framework of the information system that is 
being developed by the MEP; (ii) assess the appropriateness of the framework design based on 
international practices; and the needs of regulatory enforcement in the following 5–10 years, 
particularly the institutional structure required for the industrial waste management information 
system; and the needs for an information system for electronics waste, and an emergency 
response system; and (iii) assess the institutional capacity of the MEP and two municipal EPBs 
for applying e-governance in industrial waste management. The e-government capacity maturity 
model being developed under ADB TA (footnote 9) can be considered an assessment tool for 
this purpose. The consultants will prepare a report on the performance of the existing system 
and make recommendations on the improvement and expansion of the system as needed. 
 
11.  Output 2: Training for the development and maintenance of the industrial waste 
management  information  system  conducted. Three domestic training workshops will be 
organized to enhance institutional capacity for industrial waste information management and 
operation. One workshop will focus on the development of information system-based industrial 
waste management policies and strategies, and improvement of the institutional capacity for 
using an information system for waste management. The second workshop will be on-the-job 
training, and will focus on the operation and maintenance (O&M) of the information system, and 
data management. The third workshop will provide a “training the trainers” program to selected 
officers, who will be able to train municipal and provincial EPB staff and the private sector on the 
use  of  the  information  system  after  the  TA  completion.  Each  workshop  will  train  about 
40 participants from the MEP, and municipal and provincial EPBs.

4   
12.  The TA will also support an international training tour to learn from the experiences of an 
ADB developing member country  about the design, O&M of industrial waste management 
information system, and the use of the system to support industrial waste management and 
policy development. Participants of the training tour will be selected from officials who have 
been involved in the (i) preparation of the feasibility study of the industrial waste management 
information  system,  (ii)  TA  implementation,  and/or  (iii)  operation  and  management  of  the 
information system. The participants will prepare a report on the lessons learned from the 
training tour, and share their experience during the domestic training workshops. 
     
13.  Output 3: Management of the industrial waste management information system 
demonstrated. The TA will select two municipal EPBs to (i) demonstrate the management and 
maintenance of an industrial waste management information system, (ii) test management 
guidelines, and (iii) showcase the improved industrial waste management information system. 
The executing agency will select the demonstration bureaus based on their institutional capacity 
for  information  management  and  willingness  to  participate  in  the  demonstration  program. 
Priorities will be given to industrialized cities, such as Dalian, Guangzhou, Qingdao, Shanghai, 
or Xi’an. 
 
14.  Output 4: Guidelines on the development and management of the industrial waste 
management  information  system  prepared.  Based  on  the  assessment  of  the  existing 
industrial waste management information system and the needs for future improvement, the TA 
consultants will prepare guidelines on the development and management of the industrial waste 
management information system, which will be turned into a knowledge product at the end of 
the  TA  implementation.  The  draft  guidelines  will  be  pilot  tested  in  the  two  selected 
demonstration bureaus and presented in an international workshop, and will be revised and 
finalized  after  receiving  feedback  from  the  demonstration  and  the  international  workshop. 
International  speakers  and  local  officers  in  charge  of  industrial  waste  management  in 
government  agencies  in  selected  ADB  member  countries  will  be  invited  to  share  their 
experiences in industrial waste management. The MEP will (i) present the TA results in an 
international workshop, and (ii) share experiences with participants on the development and 
management of the industrial waste management information system. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA cost is estimated at $600,000 equivalent, of which $450,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The 
government will finance the remaining $150,000 equivalent through in-kind contributions, which 
will include (i) counterpart staff time, remuneration, and travel expenses; (ii) logistic support in 
arranging workshops and conferences; and (iii) a fully functional office space for consultants, 
with free water and utility supply, and free access to internet and photocopying. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The MEP will be the executing agency, and the Environmental Development Center 
(EDC) will be the implementing agency. The TA will be partially delegated to the EDC following 
the enhanced partnership model of the memorandum of understanding between ADB and the 
government on the “Enhanced Partnership on Technical Assistance Delegation to the Executing 
Agency” of 30 November 2009. The EDC will be responsible for developing more detailed terms 
of reference for consulting services, selection and recruitment of consultants, and supervision of 
the TA activities. ADB will sign the consultant contracts and administer the TA. The TA is the

5
second partially delegated TA to the MEP. The procurement capacity of the MEP was first 
assessed  in  2008,  and  revalidated  during  the  TA  fact-finding  mission  in  July  2010.  The 
assessment concluded that the executing and implementing agencies have sufficient resources, 
and satisfactory procurement and oversight procedures to implement the TA. The detailed 
capacity assessment report is available upon request.   
 
17.  The MEP will establish a TA steering committee, chaired by a director general in charge 
of  environmental  information  or  pollution  control;  and  comprising  representatives  from 
concerned departments from the EDC and MEP. The steering committee will provide overall 
guidance for TA implementation and endorse TA outputs. A TA management office will be set 
up in the International Cooperation Division of the EDC, which will be responsible for day-to-day 
operational matters of the TA, including supervising the TA consultants’ work plan, reviewing 
their  outputs,  and  coordinating  with  provincial  EPBs  on  the  preparation  of  the  training 
workshops and demonstration program. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months, tentatively scheduled from December 2010 
to  March  2012.  A  team  of  three  individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  conduct  the 
assessment, study, and training. Because of the TA budget constraints, the engagement of 
individual  consultants  is  more  cost-effective  and  faster  to  mobilize.  It  is  estimated  that 
25 person-months  of  consulting  services,  comprising  an  international  expert  for  5  person-
months and two national experts for 20 person-months, will be required. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. The expertise of the consultants includes industrial 
waste management, information system management, and information technology development. 
Resource persons may be recruited to conduct the training. The recruitment of consultants and 
resource persons will follow ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The EDC will also procure equipment financed by the TA following ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment procured under the TA will be turned 
over to the executing agency and the two municipal EPBs after the TA completion. 
 
19.  The outcome and outputs of the TA will be presented during domestic and international 
workshops, and posted on the ADB and MEP websites. The TA will also produce a knowledge 
product based on the guidelines on the development and management of the industrial waste 
management information system that will be produced by the TA consultants  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Capacity  Building  for  ICT-Based  Industrial  Waste 
Management and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3     
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Terms of Reference 
1.  Industrial waste management specialist/team leader (international, 5 person-months). 
The team leader will have a degree related to industrial waste management or information system. 
A postgraduate degree is desirable. The team leader will have a good understanding of industrial 
waste  management  issues  and  regulations  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and 
developed countries, and be experienced in best practices of information system management for 
industrial waste management in developed countries. The team leader will have experience in 
planning of waste management information systems and international project management. The 
team leader will 
(i)  liaise between the implementing agency and the consultant team; 
(ii)  prepare  an  overall  work  plan,  which  will  refine,  and  adjust  if  necessary,  each 
consultant’s  deliverables  and  timing  of  the  delivery;  and  ensure  the  timely 
implementation of the technical assistance (TA); 
(iii)  lead the preparation of inception, draft final, and final reports, with contribution from 
national consultants as defined in each consultant’s terms of reference; 
(iv)  prepare an assessment tool based on readily available methods, such as the e-
government maturity model being developed under Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
regional TA,1 to assess the institutional capacity of the Ministry of Environmental 
Protection  (MEP)  and  environmental  protection  bureaus  (EPBs)  for  using  an 
information  system  in  industrial  waste  management;  and  a  tool  to  assess  the 
comprehensiveness of the current waste management information system;  
(v)  identify  good  practices  of  industrial  waste  management  information  systems  in 
developed countries, such as the hazardous waste management system using the 
internet  network,  electronic  manifest  system,  emergency  response  mechanism, 
contingency planning, and chief information officer system; and recommend actions 
to be undertaken by the MEP to improve the existing industrial waste management 
information system; 
(vi)  lead  the  assessment  of  the  MEP’s  existing  framework  on  an  industrial  waste 
management  information  system  and  its  institutional  capacity  for  operating  and 
maintaining the system, and make recommendations for improvement; 
(vii)  assist  the  implementing  agency  in  selecting  two  pilot  city  EPBs,  and  prepare  a 
demonstration plan to be implemented by the national information system specialist; 
(viii)  carry out a needs assessment of the MEP and municipal EPBs for industrial waste 
management from the aspects of human resources and technical capacity; 
(ix)  prepare training materials for a training workshop on policy and strategy development 
for an industrial waste management information system based on the results of the 
needs assessment, and conduct the training workshop for about 40 national and 
provincial officials;   
(x)  prepare guidelines on industrial waste management information system, pilot test the 
guidelines  in  the  demonstration  provinces,  and  make  the  necessary  revisions  to 
finalize the guidelines. The guidelines will be transformed into a knowledge product 
that will include lessons learned from the TA as best practices for dissemination;  
(xi)  assist the implementing agency in organizing an international seminar to present the 
TA results; and 
(xii)  lead the finalization of the TA report based on comments received from ADB and the 
government, and feedback received from the international seminar.

2.  Industrial  waste  management  specialist/deputy  team  leader  (national,  10  person-
months). The industrial waste management specialist will support the team leader in coordinating 
with the executing agency and provincial governments on the TA implementation. The deputy team 
leader will have a degree related to solid waste management, environmental pollution control, and 
information system management. A postgraduate degree will be desirable. The deputy team leader 
will have hands-on experience in solid waste management information system development and 
management,  and  experience  in  leading  the  design  and  management  of  environmental 
management  information  system  projects.  Working  experience  in  donor-funded  projects  is 
preferable. The deputy team leader will 
(i)  review and prepare a report on the status and issues of industrial waste management 
in the PRC; 
(ii)  assess the national regulatory framework related to industrial waste management, 
and the institutional set-up and capacity at both MEP and provincial governments; 
(iii)  discuss with the executing agency and provincial governments major elements of an 
industrial waste management information system; 
(iv)  work together with the team leader and national information system specialist to 
propose a framework of industrial waste management information system to meet 
MEP’s medium-term needs for industrial waste management; 
(v)  assist the team leader in preparing a training program and training materials for policy 
development for the industrial waste management information system, and assist in 
conducting the training; 
(vi)  assist in the selection of two pilot cities, and lead the demonstration of the operation 
and maintenance (O&M) of the industrial waste management information system; 
(vii)  assess  and  evaluate  the  appropriateness  of  the  information  system  after  the 
demonstration period, and recommend revisions or improvements for the system and 
institutional capacity, if needed; 
(viii)  work together with the national information system management specialist to conduct 
two  training  workshops  for  about  40  national  and  provincial  officials  in  each 
workshop—one workshop will be on-the-job training on the O&M of the information 
system and data management, and the second workshop will provide a “training the 
trainers” program to prepare 40 environmental officers to train their colleagues and 
industries on the O&M of the information system after the TA completion; 
(ix)  prepare  a  report  on  the  results  of  (a)  the  assessment  of  the  system  and  the 
demonstration program, which will include recommendations for the improvement of 
the information system and additional activities to improve the institutional capacity for 
industrial waste management in provinces; and (b) the two training workshops;  
(x)  contribute to the preparation of the inception, draft final, and final TA reports; 
(xi)  assist  the  team  leader  in  organizing  the  international  seminar  and  prepare 
presentation materials; 
(xii)  participate in the international seminar in presenting the TA results; and 
(xiii)  conduct other related tasks as requested by the team leader. 
  
3.  Information  system  specialist  (national,  10  person-months).  The  information  system 
specialist will have a degree in information technology and system management, and hands-on 
experience  in  designing  and  maintaining  information  systems.  The  information  technology 
specialist will 
(i)  support  the  team  leader  in  assessing  the  existing  industrial  waste  management 
information system, and make recommendations for improvement; 
(ii)  visit  the  MEP  and  assist  the  team  leader  in  (a)  selecting  pilot  municipalities; 
(b) assessing their capacity for information management in terms of hardware and 
software, and human resources; and (c) proposing improvements as needed;

12  Appendix 3 
 
(iii)  demonstrate the O&M of the industrial waste management information system; 
(iv)  support  the  team  leader  in  preparing  the  draft  guidelines  on  development  and 
management of the industrial waste management information system; 
(v)  assess and evaluate the appropriateness of the information system and the draft 
guidelines after the demonstration period, and recommend revisions for improvement 
of the system as needed; 
(vi)  contribute to the preparation of the draft final and final TA reports; 
(vii)  work together with the deputy team leader to conduct two training workshops for 
about 40 national and provincial officials in each workshop—one workshop will be on-
the-job training on the O&M of the information system and data management, and the 
second  workshop  will  provide  a  “training  the  trainers”  program  to  prepare 
40 environmental officers to train their colleagues and industries on the O&M of the 
information system after the TA completion;  
(viii)  assist the deputy team leader to prepare a report on the results of the assessment of 
the system and the demonstration program, and the two training workshops; and 
(ix)  conduct other related tasks as may be requested by the team leader. 
  
B.  Reporting Requirement 
 
4.  The consultants will submit the following reports, all in English language, a hard copy each 
to ADB and the government. The final report will be submitted both in hard copy and in CD-ROM. 
(i)  Inception report. The team leader will submit the inception report within a month of 
the TA inception workshop, after discussions with the executing agency and the two 
national consultants. The inception report will include a work plan outlining major 
milestones of the TA activities, major outputs, the methodology and approach that will 
be adopted to deliver the outputs, draft outlines of the medium-term development 
plan, guidelines and final report, deliverables of each consultant, and the timeline of 
the deliverables.  
(ii)  Draft final report. The team leader will submit the draft final report by month 13. The 
draft final report will include (a) major outputs at various stage of TA implementation; 
(b)  a  sub-report  on  the  outcome  of  the  training  workshops  and  demonstration 
program;  (c)  a  draft  medium-term  development  plan  for  the  improvement  of  the 
industrial waste management information system; and (d) draft guidelines on the 
industrial waste management information system, which will be transformed into a 
knowledge product for dissemination.   
(iii)  Final report. The team leader, with the contribution from the national consultants, will 
finalize the final report by month 15, which will integrate comments from ADB and the 
executing agency, and feedback from the workshops. 
(iv)  Reports  on  the  training  workshops  and  demonstration  program.  The  team 
leader will prepare a summary report on the training workshop on policy development 
within a month of the training workshop. Within a month of the respective activities, 
the two national consultants will prepare a summary report each for the training 
workshops  on  on-the-job  training  and  “training  the  trainers”  program,  and  the 
demonstration program. The team leader will consolidate the summary reports in the 
draft final and final reports. 
(v)  Guidelines  on  the  development  and  management  of  an  industrial  waste 
management information system. The team leader will produce the draft guidelines 
by month 9, with the contribution from the national consultants on specific topics; and 
finalize it by month 13 after receiving comments from ADB, MEP, and local EPBs.
